title: Comparison of IMFs in NH3 and PH3

content.question: Which statement best helps to explain the observation that <math alttext="N H 3 liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> boils at <math alttext="negative 28 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>28</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, whereas <math alttext="P H 3 liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> boils at <math alttext="negative 126 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>126</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: The dispersion forces in <math alttext="N H 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are weaker than the dispersion forces in <math alttext="P H 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The dispersion forces in <math alttext="N H 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are stronger than the dipole-dipole forces in <math alttext="P H 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="N H 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> has hydrogen bonding that is stronger than the dipole-dipole forces in <math alttext="P H 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="N H 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> has hydrogen bonding that is weaker than the dipole-dipole forces in <math alttext="P H 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: <math alttext="N H 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> has hydrogen bonding that is stronger than the dipole-dipole forces in <math alttext="P H 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>PH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 4.C: Explain the connection between particulate-level and macroscopic properties of a substance using models and representations.
